text.tspan: Riverbots Designs Presents: the Stupid Ridiculously Cheap Drive Encoderâ„¢
Internally, this is just two momentary switches
When you turn the encoder, one of the switches is "pushed" slightly before the other.
When you turn the encoder the other way, the order of "pushes" is reversed.
1. No actual electronics inside (they're just switches, no LED/phototransistors or
2. We must generate our own signal, as there's none from the active componentry
3. They're less precise (oh, gee, we can only get 1cm accuracy instead of 0.1mm.
4. At least an order of magnitude cheaper and two orders of magnitude more available
"Knobs" click the switches as they pass.
How to "Fake" a Signal Similar to the Industrial Encoders:
Create a pulldown resistor configuration, so electrically the RoboRIO will "see" either 0V
or 5V depending on whether the "button" is being pressed.
When the switch is open (i.e. most of the time),
there's 0V across the resistor, since the top isn't
When the switch is tapped closed (when the rotor
trips it), there is a current going across the resistor
and the voltage (relative to ground) at the RoboRIO
I don't know which pin is which on the encoder;
